article.description: Larry Hughes scored 20 points and Antawn Jamison added 19 as the Warriors snapped their season-high seven-game losing streak with their most lopsided victory of the season, 117-88 over the struggling Cavaliers.
article.headline: Warriors end seven-game skid
article.linkText: Happy new year! Warriors earn first win in 2002
article.story:
OAKLAND, Calif. (AP) -- The Golden State Warriors' first victory in January was a pleasure to watch -- especially for their starters, who had the best seats in the house.
Jamison

Hughes

Larry Hughes scored 20 points and Antawn Jamison added 18 as the Warriors snapped their seven-game losing streak with a 117-88 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers on Wednesday night. Jason Richardson scored 15 points and Adonal Foyle had a season-high 14 as the Warriors emphatically ended their 2½-week skid with their biggest victory margin and highest point total of the season. Golden State's starters spent most of the fourth quarter on the bench -- and for once, they weren't hanging towels over their heads in disgust. "We finally got over the skid, but this league is about being consistent and winning several games in a row," Jamison said. "Let's stop the losing skid and start a winning skid." Even the vocabulary of winning is unfamiliar to the Warriors, who have missed the playoffs in a league-high seven straight seasons. But Golden State was much more energetic and effective than Cleveland, which took its eighth straight loss.

Golden State made a 19-6 run to a 15-point halftime lead, then made a 12-4 run to a 21-point lead in the third quarter -- all foreign territory to the Warriors, who have won consecutive games just once since early November. "We finally put it all together at the same time," said Hughes, who had a season-high six steals. "It felt good to get somebody down and then keep pouring it on. We could get used to that." Chris Mihm matched his career high with 20 points and had 10 rebounds for the Cavaliers, who beat the Warriors by 15 points in Cleveland two weeks ago. "Good for Chris. I didn't think he played very well," coach John Lucas said. The Cavs' 0-5 West Coast road trip hit its lowest point yet with a discouraging loss to the Pacific Division's last-place team. NBA assists leader Andre Miller had 10 points and just five assists for Cleveland, which allowed its season-high in points and took its third-worst defeat of the season -- and its second blowout loss in four days, following a 32-point loss at Portland on Sunday. "I was searching for anybody who could score and had energy, but it's been a long trip," Lucas said. "We laid a big egg. (But) the Warriors have got a lot of talent. They've got a lot of pieces. I don't know why they haven't been winning more than they have." The Cavaliers seemed to be a step slow all night, and it showed in their ponderous foul total. Four Cavs -- Jumaine Jones, Mihm, Miller and Brian Skinner -- had five personal fouls apiece with more than 14 minutes left to play, and the Warriors shot 45 free throws. "You can't really look for excuses," said Zydrunas Ilgauskas, who had 17 points and six rebounds. "We're not playing very well right now, but we're not bad enough to lose by 30 points." Lamond Murray, who scored a career-high 40 points in Cleveland's win over Golden State two weeks earlier, was nearly invisible in his return to the Bay Area, where he grew up and went to college at California. He scored five points on 2-of-6 shooting. The Warriors, clearly unfamiliar with the etiquette of blowout wins, continued to pour it on during the final meaningless minutes. Bob Sura threw an alley-oop pass off the backboard to Richardson for an electrifying reverse dunk with less than five minutes to play and a 26-point lead. "I didn't like to see it because he was so wide-open, but he was just closing out the game," Mihm said of the highlight-reel play. "They played well, and they deserved to have fun out there."

Game notes
Jones was scoreless in 28 minutes, going 0-for-7 from the field, before fouling out. He also got a technical foul. ... Murray wasn't in the Cavs' starting lineup on Tuesday night in Sacramento because he was late getting to Arco Arena. He started against the Warriors, however. ... Gilbert Arenas, the Warriors' rookie point guard, hit two layups and a 3-pointer, much to the delight of the small crowd that chanted "Gilbert! Gilbert!" when he entered the game. ... In the fourth quarter, Golden State played rookies Arenas, Richardson, Troy Murphy and Dean Oliver at the same time. The Warriors hadn't played four rookies at the same time since 1995.<

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
